awd_titl_txt: CCSS:   Collaborative Research:  Towards Privacy-Preserving Mobile Crowd Sensing: A Multi-Stage Solution
awd_abstract_narration:
Mobile devices, including smartphones and tablets, are becoming extremely prevalent nowadays. Equipped with diverse sensors, from GPS to camera, and paired with the inherent mobility of their owners, mobile devices are capable of acquiring rich information of surrounding environment. However, the wide adoption of mobile crowd sensing is largely hindered by its privacy concerns. To facilitate the functionality of each stage of mobile crowd sensing, including sensing task allocation, sensing data collection, and result aggregation, sensing devices report their location information, sensing capabilities, task preferences, and sensing results to servers that will potentially disclose their daily routings, behavior patterns and even identities. With these concerns, the overall goal of this project is to address privacy leakage issues from different stages of mobile crowd sensing. Privacy-enhanced mobile crowd sensing will attract more participants and thus accelerate the maturity of smart health care, environment monitoring, traffic surveillance, social event observation, etc. In addition, this project will also serve as a training ground for educating future decision-makers and workforce on theory and tools. 

The PIs plan to develop effective and efficient privacy preservation schemes for different stages of mobile crowd sensing. It corresponds to three closely intertwined research thrusts. Thrust I explores protecting user's sensitive information, such as locations, sensing capabilities and task preferences, from the server, while still allowing it to optimally or approximately solve task allocation problems. Rather than highly computationally-intensive crypto-based techniques, privacy preservation schemes will be designed based on decomposition methods and distributed computing algorithms. Thrust II aims to provide user's location privacy in the stage of data collection. Since locations of users, who perform sensing over the same event within a certain geographic area, are highly correlated, it deteriorates user's privacy achieved individually. To address this issue, privacy preservation schemes will be developed by exploring collaborations among users. Game theories will be adopted to further analyze users' strategies and interactions. The objective of Thrust III is to protect users' sensing data privacy during the stage of data analysis. The research is featured by jointly considering the data imperfection that is caused by the limited sensing capabilities at mobile devices and even the misbehavior of lazy/malicious users. To achieve data privacy and service accuracy simultaneously, novel schemes will be developed combining efficient matrix completion methods and advanced crypto techniques.

por.por_cntn:
Mobile devices, including smartphones and tablets, are becoming extremely prevalent nowadays. Equipped with diverse sensors, from GPS to camera, and paired with the inherent mobility of their owners, mobile devices are capable of acquiring rich information of surrounding environment. However, the wide adoption of mobile crowd sensing (MCS) is largely hindered by its privacy concerns. To facilitate the functionality of each stage of mobile crowd sensing, including sensing task allocation, sensing data collection, and result aggregation, sensing devices report their location information, sensing capabilities, task preferences, and sensing results to servers that will potentially disclose their daily routings, behavior patterns and even identities. With these concerns, the overall goal of this project is to address privacy leakage issues from different stages of mobile crowd sensing. 

By leveraging the differential privacy mechanism, the PI has developed manageable privacy preservation for mobile crowdsensing users in terms of location privacy, bid privacy, and task allocation privacy. The team has validated from both theoretical and implementation perspective that the proposed light-weighted privacy preservation techniques work better than traditional crypto-based solutions in terms of efficiency, energy saving, and usability. Realizing that workers perceive their location privacy differently, the team constructed an auction-based trading market, facilitating location privacy trading between workers and the platform in MCS. Each worker can decide how much location privacy to disclose to the platform based on its own location privacy leakage budget. Our mechanism enables the platform to select a suitable set of winning workers to achieve desirable service accuracy. The PI also investigated secure task allocation in MCS. In an ideal scenario, workers are trusted to report their accurate parameters to the platform, so that task allocation optimization problems can be correctly formulated and calculated. Nonetheless, malicious workers can explore illegal benefit gain by simply uploading falsified parameters. Even worse, such an attack is difficult to detect. To defend this attack, we novelly leverage incentive mechanism design. Workers are motivated to report desirable ''indicators'', based on which the platform can still obtain the accurate task allocation profile even without workers' genuine parameters. The effectiveness and efficiency of our mechanism is validated through both formal analysis and extensive simulation results. The PI also designed privacy-preserving data analytical approaches for large-scale MCS systems. The major challenge for current MCS data aggregation is that MCS users must submit their data to a centralized infrastructure for processing. For many applications performing data analytics, they usually require the data should be trained after the aggregation, which obviously put privacy concerns in danger. The PI has proposed distributed learning approaches to let individual MCS users train their local data and contribute to the global training results for data analytics. By only sharing the intermediate parameters of training results, the MCS data privacy has been well preserved. All the above results have been experimentally verified using real-world datafiles.

The developed privacy-preserving techniques in this project can greatly enhance the mobile users’ privacy when participating a diverse range of MCS applications in future wireless systems. Meanwhile, the mobile data offloading schemes can relieve the data traffic from the infrastructure to users, and further reduce the network congestion in crowded areas, which will make significant progress and generate more business opportunities in building future smart cities. The investigation on potential wireless attacks to IoT devices can also provide insight for future wireless device manufacturing. The proposed defensive mechanisms can be generally deployed in many wireless application scenarios, such as industrial IoT, smart agriculture, and smart healthcare. During this project duration, the PI has supported two Ph.D. students. Under the PI’s supervision, the team has produced 9 high-quality technical papers published in highly reputable venues in research community. The team also share the technical results to a broader range of students at University of Nevada Reno and The University of Texas at Arlington.
